Over the next ten years, the couple self-funded four more IVF and frozen embryo cycles, which all led to pregnancies that sadly never got past  weeks. The procedures cost them over £, of their savings. The last ten years have just gone in the blink of an eye because weaposve not been able to do things other people enjoy,” Danielle-Eve said. Weaposre looking back and I just feel like our last ten years have been on hold because we always thought next year weaposre not going to go on holidayI get pregnant. At the start of every year weaposve not been able to plan what we do.Our hearts have been on hold and our wallets have been on hold. Danielle-Eve did manage to get pregnant twice in , but those pregnancies also resulted in miscarriages - meaning she lost six babies over a ten year period. story: AdvertorialFind out the moving story behind our masthead masterpieceNotice something dferent  The Mirror changed its masthead for the first time, thanks to a National Lottery funded art projectmirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialSiddharth Gadiyar with his mum, SusmithaWhen Siddharth Gadiyar, , enters the art studio, the dficulties surrounding his autism and behavioural needs melt away and his creativity is poured on to the giant canvases propped in front of him. The resulting pieces are so impressive that we’ve even changed our masthead to celebrate how art can reach all people. Every Friday, Sid attends a session with National Lottery-funded Project Art Works in Hastings. “It’s one of the best things that happens in Sid’s le,” says his mother, Susmitha. “He has so many behavioural challenges on top of his autism, ADHD, severe learning disability and severe speech and language impairment, I didn’t think they’d take him. But when I explained these to Tim at Project Art Works, a National Lottery-funded collective of neuroerse artists and activists, he just told me to bring him.  Sid is blissfully unaware of his talent or anything that happens before or after painting. All he knows is that it brings him great joy, calm and happiness.” Sid has been attending Project Art Works for over three years and it’s been a leline for both him and his family. He is given paints and large canvases to create his artworks. The most moving picture for everyone involved was one he dedicated to his mum, inscribing the words “Siddharth love Mummy” over and over again. “It was the first time in his le that he had conveyed that message to me,” says Susmitha. “I’m so grateful for the support I get from Project Art Works, the carers who support my trips and the National Lottery players who make it all possible.”By playing The National Lottery, you raise £M for good causes every week*, just like Project Artworks. Kate and Gerry McCann still hope she will be found alive,  years after she vanished on holiday in Portugal in , days before her fourth birthday. They said in a poignant message: “We love you and are waiting for you.” Devoted Kate and Gerry marked daughter Madeleine’s th birthday on Wednesday by leaving cards and gts in her room, untouched since she vanished  years ago. The couple posted a photo of her on the Find Madeleine campaign Facebook page, writing alongside it: “Happy th birthday Madeleine.  “We love you and we’re waiting for you and we’re never going to give up.” Kate, , and Gerry, , had asked pals to mark the day in a low-key manner. The Facebook post came a week after they marked the “particularly poignant” th anniversary of her disappearance. Madeleine went missing from her family’s holiday apartment in the Algarve resort of Praia da Luz days before her fourth birthday in May .  Prosecutors want to question German paedophile Christian Brueckner over her disappearance and claim to have evidence that she is dead. Scotland Yard’s hunt for Madeleine’s abductor continues, with four detectives still working on Operation Grange. Sue Radford, who has a staggering  children, gave the advice to her daughter Chloe, , before she left to set up home with her partner Jake, suggesting she live with him for a while before settling down. Chloe was the eldest among the  children Sue, , and her husband Noel, , had still living at home, They are parents to Chris, , Sophie, , Chloe, , Jack, , Daniel, , Luke, , Millie, , Katie, , James, , Ellie, , Aimee, , Josh, , Max, , Tillie, , Oscar, nine, Casper, eight, Hallie, five, Phoebe, four, Archie, three, Bonnie, two, Heidie, one, and also baby Alfie, who was sadly still born on July , .  The couple might have expected their home to be a little quieter now there are  children left living there. But Sue said on their Youtube channel that there had been “bedroom wars” as a result, with the other older children now bidding for the room. “We’ve had bedroom wars between Katie and Luke,” Sue said. “We decided Katie was probably better having it as there is four in that bedroom and only James and Luke in the bedroom at the front.” She also said she had urged Chloe to take things slowly with her boyfriend Jake, and to live with him and his mum before buying a house.  “Last weekend when we were away in Center Parcs Chloe moved in with her boyfriend which was a big deal,” Sue explained. “She wants to get a mortgage but I said instead of jumping in and getting a mortgage together before you’ve lived together, please live together and seeyou like each other and get on really well. “It’s a big dealyou then realise actually living together you don’t get on too well.” Chloe was still living at the family’s ten-bedroom home in Morecambe, Lancashire, before then. The new baby will be born to Chris, who already has two children, Maisie, three, and Jacob, one, in September. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA new mum told a tennis-ball sized cancerous breast tumour was probably a blocked milk duct laughed when she was finally diagnosed.Beccie Lopez began noticing what looked like cellulite and a dimpling of the skin on her right breast just three months after giving birth to her son.The -year-old beautician initially put it down to “something to do with having the baby and the changes in your body”. But months later she could feel a large lump that remained for several weeks, and she began to grow concerned. “When I was looking at myself and I flattened my skin I could see it,” Beccie told the Mirror. “I got my mum to come and have a feel and she could see the dimpling of the skin and she said aposyou need to ring the doctor ASAPapos.” Beccie rang her GP the next day and as soon as she mentioned the dimpling of the skin she said she was referred to hospital straight away, due to it being a common sign of aggressive cancer.Are you going through a similar journey to Beccie  Let us know at webnews@mirror “Thankfully, mine wasnapost aggressive. But it was growing fast, it was a grade ,” Beccie, from Gravesend, Kent, explained. She said even the nurses were shocked when tests confirmed it was cancer, partly due to her age and the fact she has no history of the disease in her family. “Just like everyone  they thought it was a blocked milk duct and thataposs what I thought it was going to be,” she explained. Recalling when she was told, she said: “I walked into the room, there was five nurses there...they said aposIaposm sorry, itaposs not looking goodapos.  “At the time I laughed, Iaposm the sort of person I donapost know how to be when itaposs that sort of thing. Do I laugh or do I cry  “They kept talking to me, and I said to them aposIaposm not taking anything in youaposre saying to meapos, I just wanted to get out. “But they have to go through it. The little bits about whataposs going to happen next. “Obviously, they didnapost know what stage it was or anything like that, so my first question was aposam I going to die apos “Thataposs all I cared about. Iaposve got a little boy. I turned  in September and found out in February, and I thought this sort of thing canapost be happening.”  In the time since first beginning tests, Beccie developed almost all of the telltale signs, including an inverted nipple, a change in her skin and the shape of her breast, and shooting pains. Within four weeks of diagnosis she had her mastectomy, where the tumour and seven swollen lymph nodes were removed. These came back clear following a biopsy, confirming the cancer hadnapost spread to them. But during surgery a second cancerous growth was found next to the first, which was removed along with the right breast. Beccie must now wait months for a second mastectomy to remove the left breast, as well as reconstruction work due to delays brought about by the Covid pandemic. She is due start chemotherapy this month.  “The whole thing has been surreal. Even to this day, itaposs still so surreal,” she said. “It feels even when I look down and Iaposve not got my breast anymore it doesnapost feel real.” She said prior to her diagnosis she had googled her symptoms and was ready to hear the worst. “I went in there prepared to be told it was either a benign tumour but Iaposve got to have surgery, or cancer,” she added. She continued: “Iaposve accepted it now. I feel quite well, to be fair. I think that might change when my hair starts to fall out and I start to go through chemotherapy, thataposs when itaposs going to feel real to me.” In the meantime, Beccie is in a race against time to complete fertility treatment before chemo starts on May .

Irene Payne raised a glass of bubbly to toast her first time outdoors in more than a year. Care home staff arranged the surprise reunion with her daughter Sandra Pocock, , after the great-great gran was forced apart from her family due to the pandemic. An emotional Irene can be heard exclaiming hello sweetheart as she spotted her daughter outside Fernhill House, Worcester. Ireneaposs carer wheeled her through the home and she was applauded by staff who formed a guard of honour, complete with balloons and confetti.  BirminghamLive reports how the delighted pair clinked glasses and enjoyed a short walk around her village to give Irene her first taste of freedom since February last year.She is seen enjoying the emotional reunion and shouting Cheers everyone! as she toasted her carers and family. Retired nurse Irene moved into the care home following a hip injury and was unable to see her family properly until Covid restrictions were recently eased.  Sandra, of Chippenham, Wilts., said: The home rang me last Wednesday to askI would like to take mum out because of the Covid restrictions being relaxed and go out for a short walk. “Obviously I was over the moon to take her. I went in on Thursday, had my tests like I always do and they brought mum out to me. “She was completely unaware that it was going to happen. “They were clapping her out, there were balloons and a confetti shower and glasses of fizz for me to hold out to her. She does enjoy a glass of wine, so it was fantastic to celebrate with her.  “Mum was just overwhelmed, it was amazing. She had no idea, so it was a total surprise and really lovely. “Then I took her round the village which was really nice because she hadn’t been able to see the area since moving  months ago. “She was delighted to see the trees, be in the fresh air and hear the birds singing. It was just bliss. “It was wonderful to see her smiley face.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum-of-two has completely transformed a run-down church building into a luxury eight-bed family home, having done much of the renovation work herself. Emily Barratt and her husband purchased the £, property in Middleton in January , when it was in dire need of an upgrade. The building was in a poor state, with the previous owners’ belongings strewn across the house, as well as a leaking roof and battered old windows which desperately needed to be replaced. We lived in a very small cottage built in  prior to this, so I was keen to have lots of space. I saw so much potential with this big, beautul building that had such a lovely history, and thought it would make the perfect family home,” explained Emily, who works as a pottery artist.  The -year-old took time off work to focus on doing up the house, as well as home schooling seven-year-old Minnie and six-year-old Rory throughout the pandemic. Emily, who hails from Rochdale, had help from builders to fix the leak in the roof, fit  new windows and knocking down the wall between the kitchen and the dining room, before she embarked on the rest of the renovations all by herself. She began by pulling down the ceiling in the master bedroom to expose the original church beams, before plastering the remainder of the rooms and moving onto the aesthetics and transforming them one by one.  The hardest part was tiling the floors and laying the carpets. I taught myself to do both, but they are quite physical and Iaposm not the strongest person out there,” Emily said. “I do DIY every day, including painting, tiling and upcycling furniture.” She added: I did all the ling and wallpapering myself and also sanded all the beams in our bedroom. I also painted the outside the house - but I still have a few other sides left to do. I love DIY, I find it really addictive and Iaposll give anything a go other than electrics.  The kitchen, which turned out to be the most expensive thanks to all new appliances, was transformed from dark flooring and old fashioned cabinets to having sleek stone flooring and all modern countertops. Meanwhile, the bathroom has also been completely modernised with black, white and grey tiles, a claw-foot tub, and a walk-in shower. Elsewhere in the home, the bedrooms have all been totally revamped, including the childrenaposs rooms which are now colourful and exciting, while being tailored to each of their personalities.  But, once all the bedrooms were sorted, Emily turned her attention to creating the family’s very own gym, in place of what used to be an old bedroom. Elsewhere, she turned a dinghy old garage into a luxurious, fully stocked bar with cool lighting and an area for live music. While the house isn’t finished just yet, Emily recently had someone come and value the home, which is now worth an eyewatering £, - £, more than it was purchased for.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice A mum-of-five killed in an alleged hit and run was called by her kidsapos school as she lay dying to say she was late picking up her child, it is claimed. ‘Loving soul’ Iram Shehzadi, , was on her way to collect her daughter when she was struck in Bradford, West Yorkshire, on Monday afternoon. As paramedics worked in vain to save her le her mobile rang as the school called to ask why she was running late to pick up her child, a witness to the horric crash claims. Police are quizzing  -year-old driver arrested on suspicion of the murder of Mrs Shehzad, who died less than  yards from her home.The mum died when a grey Citroen C ploughed into her near a junction in the neighbourhood, police say. A man who raced to the scene after hearing the crash described a bloodbath, as the victim was carried on the bonnet before the vehicle crashed into boulders beside a grassed area and she was catapulted -ft, hitting a tree head-first. A -year-old man was arrested a short time later, West Yorkshire Police said. Mrs Shehzadi, has an -year-old son, along with two boys and two girls. She was taking her usual daily route to pick up the youngest, her seven-year-old daughter, when she was killed at pm. Uzmat Munir, , a bank employee, was working from his home overlooking the grassed area on Monday afternoon when he heard a massive bang. “I saw the lady laying face down on the grass next to the tree. The car was empty and smashed into the rocks, he said. “My neighbour called an ambulance and we tried to help the lady, but none of us knew CPR. “There was about five of us stood around, not knowing what to do. A woman came before the ambulance arrived and turned her over and tried to revive her, but the poor lady was obviously dead.There was blood flowing from her mouth and a head wound - it was a bloodbath. “The car had hit her, carried on the bonnet and after it hit the rocks, she had flown into the tree. It looked like she had hit her head on the tree.”  Flowers have since laid below the tree, and police remained in the area on Wednesday. Mr Munir added:“I heard that whilst the paramedics tried to resuscitate the woman, her mobile phone rang, and it was the school ringing to let her know she was late picking her kid up.” The victimaposs neighbour Rukhsana Kausar, , said: ”She lived with her husband and five children and was devoted to her children. “Iram had gone to pick up her young daughter, like she does every day at that time, and this terrible thing has happened.” Rehana Nawaz, , who lives on the street where the mum was hit, said: ”I heard a lot of noise and thought it was a fight at first. “I went down and saw her laying down on the ground, face down. I asked a couple of guys standing there to roll her over onto her back. “You could see she had a massive injury to the right side of her head and there was a lot of blood coming from her mouth. “My sister-in-law, who is a teacher and knows CPR, tried about  compressions and then the ambulance arrived. “At first I thought she had been the driver of the car and I saw car keys on the ground beside the vehicle, but the I was told by someone there that the driver had run off. “One of the men who was first on the scene had held her hand and she looked at him as she took her last breath and passed away. “She took that same route every day at the same time to pick up her little girl.” Haris, Mrs Shehzadi’s nephew, said: “It has hit the family, especially her children, really hard. “She was a very good lady who always kept herself to herself. She has helped everybody out. She had a lot of respect from the area. “I used to live near her and see her every day going to pick up her kids from school. “The family are going to be traumatised, she did not deserve this at all.” Another relative said: I went to pay my respects to her husband yesterday and he is still in shock. He still thinks she is coming back, it hasnapost sunk in yet.

Former councillor Jackie Earl says its outside tables are too close to her home. There is six-foot wall between her property and the courtyard but her home overlooks the increasingly busy outside space. The grandmother-of-seven has invested a lot of money and effort into renovating her own home in line with conservation area rules. She believes her privacy had been infringed by the courtyard’s use. And she was shocked with the way the bar had gone about the change and quietly introduced the outside seating. She told Gazettelive : You wouldn’t believe it. I can touch an umbrella from my garden wall.“I’ve lived here all my le and I’ve no issue with people making money out of it. “We had a newsagent’s for more than  years, so I understand all about businesses. “But not having this three feet from your house.” Her own home is renovated according to the market town of Yarmaposs own conservation area rules. But the wine bar, called Fourteen Drops in Stockton, County Durham, put tables at the back to serve customers during lockdown.  Pubs and restaurants will only be allowed to serve people who are sitting outside until May  when lockdown rules are relaxed further. They’ve ridden roughshod over us really, it’s an entitlement thing. WhatI’d gone and done that in front of their house  They wouldn’t like a pop up bar.  The bar was allowed to put the tables out after getting ‘temporary event notices according to reports. A council spokesman said: We’ve taken a flexible approach to supporting businesses as they get back on their feet, and Fourteen Drops was recently granted a Temporary Events Notice allowing use of the rear courtyard.

story: News ways Covid was preventable pandemic - from lost February to reckless presidentsAn eight-day delay in declaring a global emergency and winner takes all battle for PPE are among the key findings of a scathing report commissioned by the World Health OrganisationmirrorShareCommentsByAlex Bellotti:,  MAY NewsMedical workers take swab samples from residents to be tested for Covid- in a street in Wuhan " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAt least .million lives could have been saved during the Covid- crisis, which has been labelled a apospreventable pandemicapos in a scathing piece of research. A lack of international leadership, an eight-day delay in declaring a global emergency and reluctance to impose travel restrictions are among the key findings by an independent report commissioned by the World Health Organisation. Calling for wide-ranging reforms to the WHO and for an international council to be established to transform preparation and response, the report lays out bold measures to make the current global crisis the last pandemic. The situation we find ourselves in today could have been prevented,  co-chair Ellen Johnson Sirleaf said at the launch of the report. It is due to a myriad of failures, gaps and delays in preparedness and response.Here are the key errors that created a toxic cocktail for the spread of coronavirus.Eight-day delay in declaring global emergency Chinese authorities first confirmed they were treating dozens of cases of pneumonia sparked by an unknown cause in Wuhan on December , . At the time, there was no evidence the virus could be rapidly spread by humans, but the report suggests the World Health Organisation was slow to act as the disease gained momentum.  “Clinicians in Wuhan acted quickly when they recognised iniduals in a cluster of pneumonia cases that were not normal,” said Sirleaf, adding that the alert was quickly picked up by neighbouring countries and the media. “This shows the benefit and speed of open-source reporting, but then the systems that were meant to validate and respond to this alert were too slow. The alert system does not operate with sufficient speed when faced with a fast-moving respiratory pathogen.” The report suggests the World Health Organisation was hindered by regulations that need rethinking and should have declared a global health emergency by January  - eight days before it eventually did so.On January , a -year-old woman suffering a fever, cough and sore throat arrived from Wuhan in the UK, before being confirmed as Britainaposs first coronavirus case.By the time a global emergency was declared, the virus has already spread to countries including Thailand and the US, with around  confirmed cases and  reported dead. aposLost monthapos of February Following the declaration, however, the report suggests too many countries were slow to act and tighten their borders, meaning February was a lost month in the fight against the virus. If travel restrictions had been imposed more quickly, more widely, again that would have been a serious inhibition on the rapid transmission of the disease, said the aposs co-chair Helen Clark, the former prime minister of New Zealand.  New Zealandaposs quick response to the virus was hailed as an early success story in the pandemic, with the nation currently reporting only  Covid deaths since the outbreak began. On February , a man in the Philippines became the first person outside China to die of Covid-. New Zealand banned entries to any foreigners coming from or through the country, while forcing nationals ing from there to isolate for  days. The UKaposs response was less severe. Between January and March , Britain imposed quarantine measures on  people travelling from Wuhan, while asking travellers from high-risk countries including China, Iran and Northern Italy to voluntarily isolate for  days. However, these self-isolation requirements were withdrawn on March  -  days before the UK went into lockdown. The report adds: “Countries with the ambition to aggressively contain and stop the spread whenever and wherever it occurs have shown that this is possible. Reckless leaders aposdevalued scienceapos International leaders who devalued science have also been criticised by the study, which claims they denied the potential impact of the pandemic, delayed comprehensive action, and allowed distrust to undermine efforts.Arguably the most high profile example was former US president Donald Trump, who was widely rebuked for his downplaying of and outright denial of the virus.In January , after the first Covid case in the US was confirmed, he said: “It’s one person coming in from China. We have it under control. It’s going to be just fine.” The next month he boasted, It’s going to disappear. One day – it’s like a miracle – it will disappear, later prompting outcry for suggesting the virus could be combated by injecting bleach.  The US currently has recorded , Covid deaths, the highest rate in the world, followed by Brazil on , deaths. Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro infamously railed against other nationaposs lockdown measures as the pandemic unfolded, saying of the virus: Itaposs just a little flu or the snfles. Speaking in late March , he stood firm against calls for tougher measures, insisting: “Our lives have to go on. Jobs must be kept... We must, yes, get back to normal. The countryaposs slow vaccination rollout has since seen Bolsonaroaposs regime accused of “homicidal negligence” by the Brazilian press. Sceptical leaders from nations also including Tanzania and Turkmenistan - whose president suggested a herb could keep the virus at bay - were dubbed the aposostrich allianceapos for burying their heads in the sand. aposWinner takes allapos battle for PPE Many nations were unprepared for a pandemic and only spurred into action when hospital ICU beds began to fill, said Clark. She added: By then it was too late to avert the pandemicaposs impact. What followed then was a winner takes all scramble for PPE and therapeutics. Globally, health workers were tested to their limits and the rates of infection, illness and death soared and continue to soar.” Last May, the Mirror told how doctors completely ran out of essential items of PPE while fighting on the NHS frontline.One ICU doctor working at a London hospital said: “I have had to treat patients without a gown on because we have completely run out. Just my scrubs, with gloves and a mask. “One member of staff has stopped coming to work because her mum has Type  diabetes and without PPE, she’s terried she’ll infect her. I often find myself standing in front of a patient, knowing I’m not protected enough.”A report by thealso found that government stockpiles containing protective equipment for healthcare workers in the event of a pandemic fell in value by almost  per cent in the six years up to .aposPandemic of inequalityapos The aposs experts warn that Covid- has been a pandemic of inequality, exacerbated between and within countries. The crisis has been particularly devastating in impoverished nations like India, where tens of millions of residents have been plunged into poverty since the outbreak.

title: i led nail biting cave
story: NewsI led nail-biting cave rescue of Thai football team - we had to drug them with ketamineEXCLUSIVE: Forced to sedate trapped children and infamously called up by Elon Musk, Brit er John Volanthen recalls the great escape that gripped the worldmirrorShareCommentsByAlex Bellotti:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsBritish cave-er John Volanthen walks out from Tham Luang Nang Non cave on June ,  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeIt was the smell that made John Volanthen fear the worst when he first came up for air. Turning to his companion Rick Stanton, the er assumed it was the odour of rotting corpses - in fact, it belonged to a rather pungent make-sht toilet spot a mile inside the cavernous Thai cave they were desperately searching. If youaposve got to pick something to smell, itaposs much better to have that and see  Thai kids alive, quips the -year-old now. It was just one of the countless surreal moments in a rescue mission that gripped the world, as everyone from the US military to Elon Musk piled in to save the Wild Boars soccer team trapped against a rising tide. A world-renowned cave er for  years, John and two fellow Brits were parachuted in to spearhead the operation - battling against insurmountable odds to retrieve the entire group alive and well. In his new book, Thirteen Lessons That Saved Thirteen Lives, John reveals the nail-biting moments that left him preparing for the worst - from sedating the boys with ketamine to the exhausting swim for survival. aposI imagined bumping into bodiesapos John first realised his services were in order when he read the story on BBC news:  young soccer players and their coach had become trapped in the Tham Luang Nang Non cave after venturing in for an initiation ceremony on June , . Contacting fellow Brit Vernon Unsworth, who was already at the scene, John and Rick flew out to Thailand - but the operation was already growing out of control. When we arrived there was a fair bit of chaos, says John. Lots of organisations were milling round, nobody actually seemed to know what they had to do. On top of that, the water had been rising steadily, advancing towards the entrance to the cave.  Earning the trust of the US military who were plotting the mission alongside the Thai Navy Seals, the Brits took a step back and assessed their options. With the water reaching dangerously high levels, there was little to do but wait for days until they could enter the cave. As the press poured in from across the globe, the forces on the ground contemplated the grim reality of the situation - with the flooding so severe, there was little chance the football team would be alive. I tend to do a lot of visualisations, says John, from Bristol, who has previously carried out cave ing missions in body recovery. In my mind I had run through crawling underwater upstream against the flow, reaching a swirling point of the cave and quite literally bumping into childrenaposs bodies, imagining how they might spin in the flow. Itaposs a macabre thing to do, but Iaposd rather ready myself for it ahead of time than find it and be unprepared for it. Itaposs a case of hoping for the best, but preparing for the worst. During their first expedition into the cave, however, John and Rick were surprised to come across another team - four Thai water workers who had become trapped during an earlier rescue attempt. Quickly deciding to take them to safety, the Brits tucked the workers under their arms in a manoeuvre John likens to an underwater wrestling match. Yet the bizarre discovery paled in comparison to what they found next. aposFinding them alive  That was the easy partapos On July  - a week since the alarm was raised - the waters had finally reached a safe enough level for John and Rick to search the cave further. Venturing a mile in, the pair eventually emerged into an opening. At first, they were hit by the terrible smell - but then noticed flashes of light bouncing around the pitch-black chamber. They had found the Wild Boars.  Armed with cameras to record the journey and provide proof of le, Rick inspected the faces in complete disbelief. I hadnapost expected all the children to survive. I wanted to capture the faces of those who were alive so we could work out who was not, he explains. Once we finished filming, we counted to  and they were all alive. Unbelievable. On the video, as I start climbing the mud bank where theyaposre sheltering, thereaposs a funny moment where I say a couple of times aposbelieveapos. Iaposm just trying to convince myself that the situation really is real. When the news broke of the boysapos survival, millions breathed a sigh of relief. But John couldnapost afford to be so complacent - he knew the hardest leg of their journey was yet to come. What we were trying to do had never been done before, he says. Itaposs almost unimaginable in a modern western society that you can have  happy, smiley children that are beyond help. Yet, Iaposve always known that in cave ing explorations, you can be beyond a long, flooded section of cave and you can be alive there, but youaposre slowly dying. Thereaposs no way of sustaining le. To explain that concept is quite dficult, as people didnapost want to hear that. Because weaposd found them, people seemed to think it was a done deal. Really, it hadnapost been started. Emerging back alone from the cave, the ers began plotting how to rescue the team and their coach. John knew thatthey stayed there much longer, with oxygen quickly depleting, not one of them would survive.  While the experts ignored the buzz of the international media, hundreds of offers of help were coming from all corners of the globe. Notably, one such offer was from Tesla founder Elon Musk, who rang them suggesting he could supply a small submarine to assist the operation. John, a self-confessed fan of the billionaireaposs work, urged his colleagues to hear him out. I said to Rick, aposThis is a person with almost limitless resources. We would be foolish to turn down this assistance.apos It seemed thatanyone was going to pull of some sort of wild card, he had the experience, the money and the engineering to do so. Ultimately it wasnapost something that would have been useful. But there were hundreds of people offering suggestions andyou have to pick someone thataposs credible, he was probably very high up on that list.Muskaposs involvement took a infamous turn once his help was turned down. The billionaire took to Twitter calling Vernon a pedo guy, leading to a highly-publicised defamation suit he eventually won.I wasnapost involved in the name calling and stuff that happened afterwards, says John. It was a shame really as it detracted from the whole rescue mission. Boys drugged with ketamine The ersapos previous rescue of the water workers had taught them one key lesson as they made preparations to retrieve the soccer team. Even in that short journey back, the workers had struggled against the water and risked losing sight of the navigation line. The solution was a sobering one: the boys would have to be sedated.  We knew that there was no way we could bring the boys out conscious through a mile of flooded passage, says John. At some point they would panic, and that had been underlined by bringing these adult male water workers from what was perhaps  metres of passage. Bringing in expert anaesthetist Richard Harris, the team were armed with a mixture of ketamine, xanax and atropine. The rescue mission was ready to go. aposWe put them underwater - and they stopped breathingapos Emerging in the cave chamber, John was handed the responsibility of bringing three of the children to safety. Initially believing they might be semi-conscious for the journey, he now knew he would have to carry them completely unconscious. Upon administering the drugs, however, they were faced with a terrying moment before the journey had even begun.  When we put the childrenaposs faces underwater they stopped breathing for a period of time, says John. Perhaps it was the cold water, but they would tense up, then start relaxing. I certainly had an issue with my second lad where he stopped breathing for some period of time. Itaposs not a good situation to be in. Youaposve got a healthyish child and because youaposre so far from help, youaposre on your own. Feeling completely exhausted after days of non-stop preparations, the er admits at that moment he desperately wanted it to be over. Strapping on the childrenaposs masks, though, he broke the journey ahead into small checkpoints in his mind - then took the plunge. I was overwhelmingly tired and as is often the case with dficult things in all walks of le, the whole problem is too much to think about, John says of the journey back. I tend to break things down into small chunks and itaposs just a case of moving forwards, one step at a time and ticking those little jobs off. The visibility is often so bad that you canapost see the child youaposre carrying. Youaposve got one hand on the line, youaposre cradling the child under your chest. The only way you know theyaposre still alive is that you can feel bubbles rising from the regulator attached to their mask.  The eyes of the world were fixated on the ers, but John says he simply focused on the three boys under his care. If there was a mistake to be made on this mission, he vowed, it wouldnapost be his. Swimming through what he describes as cold coffee, he took care to guide the unconscious childrenaposs bodies while not disturbing their masks, which could have led to them drowning on the spot. Just metres from the exit, he came across a heart-stopping problem. I suddenly had a moment quite close to the end of the e where suddenly the child wouldnapost move forwards, says John. In the poor visibility I had to park him on the bottom and feel down the side of his body, looking for a reason why he wouldnapost move forwards. I found a piece of old telephone wire that had wound round one of his legs, so I had to cut that. All of this is done in visibility of perhaps six inches. Played by Colin Farrell in Hollywood blockbuster The final result was a triumph against all odds. By July , all  boys and the coach were rescued alive and taken to hospital for treatment. Reflecting on his teamaposs success, John admits his own sense of relief was in being able to hold my head up high - albeit in typically macabre fashion. Quite oftenyou recover bodies, the relatives want to thank you for doing that and thataposs part of their healing process, he says. Iaposve had to say aposIaposm sorry for your lossapos quite a lot. I was just very pleased not to have to meet a parent of a Wild Boar and say that. It might sound a bit negative, but I could hold my head up high. We did what we said we could do.

picturesque Fe golf club, wrecking a putting green and furniture and causing £, worth of damage.Club officials at Balbirnie Park Golf Club in Markinch opened on Sunday to find a number of bins ripped from walls and crushed, one of the greens damaged and furniture missing.The incident happened at the Balbirnie Park Golf Course sometime between pm on Saturday and .am on Sunday.An estimated £, worth of damage was caused across the course with the greens, and associated fixtures and fittings being targeted.Greenkeepers were called in to conduct an emergency repair in order for the club to remain open.The incidents are the latest in a spate of vandalism and anti-social behaviour suffered by the club in recent months, prompting club officials to call for increased police patrols of the area in a bid to deter further damage.Club captain, George Allan, said the club had suffered numerous incidents, despite increasing security at the course.He said: “It’s hugely frustrating for the club’s staff who work tirelessly to keep the course in top condition.“Saturday’s damage included bins ripped from the walls, which were crushed and then dug into the turf on one of our green.“I’m at a loss to see how anyone can get pleasure out of such destruction.“Our greenkeepers had to undertake an emergency repair and did a great job so members could continue playing.“Tee markers and flags have also gone missing, while furniture was also removed which all has to be replaced at a cost to the club.“I’ve confronted a few youths regarding but they just laugh and walk off, they have no respect for the club or its members.“We’ve had continuing problems with petty vandalism for months and are to meet with the police this week to discuss ways in which they and us can stop further vandalism.”Inspector Kirk Donnelly from Glenrothes Police Station said: “It is disappointing to hear of this mindless act of vandalism that has caused considerable damage to the Balbirnie Golf Course.“There is a minority in our community who feel this sort of behaviour is acceptable, but I want to be clear, that it is not.“I am aware of a number of reports from members of the public recently of young people gathering in this area, who are abusing alcohol, littering and becoming involved in antisocial behaviour.“Officers are working with Fe Council and the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service to ensure the area is patrolled regularly, but I would also urge the parents and s of young people to encourage them against gathering in groups and remind them that anti-social behaviour of any kind will not be tolerated.“We are following lines of enquiry into this incident of vandalism and I am appealing to anyone who may have been in the area at the time and saw anything to contact the police.”Newsletter shut down permanently.In a letter circulated to members, the company announced that despite their best efforts, the premises will not reopen.And gym users who had been paying since lockdown will not be reimbursed by Anytime Fitness.It had been shut since December due to Covid restrictions but had not reopened last month.The Press and Journal previously reported that all the gym equipment had been removed from the massive unit at Elgin Retail Park.The franchise owner Chris McIntyre has also disappeared and dodged all calls and messages from worried gym users who were unsure about their future.It is understood a number of members had been paying their gym fees throughout lockdown in an agreement with the business.In the letter, Anytime Fitness confirmed that they had tried to contact the current business owner but did not have any success.The statement read: #The Anytime Fitness UK Support Office has been trying hard to make contact with Plus Fitness Limited, the current business owner, to help reach an agreement with the landlord and transition the club to new ownership to secure the future of Anytime Fitness Elgin.#Unfortunately, all attempts have proven unsuccessful.#We appreciate that this is a hugely disappointing outcome for all of you and we want to take this opportunity to assure you that we have done all we can to try and prevent the permanent closure.#We understand that many of you have been paying membership fees throughout the ious lockdown closure on the understanding that the club would reopen once restrictions have been lted.#Anytime Fitness also confirmed that the site in Elgin was an independent franchise business, and all membership fees were paid to Plus Fitness Ltd.This means that they are not liable for any reimbursement to members, which must be done through Plus Fitness Ltd.The owner of that business, Chris McIntyre, has been uncontactable since the news broke about the gym equipment going missing.It is the only -hour gym in or.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remFor the Sullivan family, every meal is like a large-scale catering event – and a day out takes military-level organisational skills.Because this Moray family could make their own football team – and even have the luxury of two subs on the bench.Zoe and Ben Sullivan and their brood, ranging in age from two to , are one of Britain’s biggest families.The Lossiemouth family are set to hit the small screen on Thursday night as part of an ITV programme about budgeting for so many kids.But here, Zoe gives an insight into the day-to-day mechanics of keeping things running like clockwork, how she and Ben ended up with such a big clan # and what it’s really like to shop for .Ben, , and Zoe, , are both from the same part of Cornwall and grew up together. After moving away from the area separately as young adults, they got together when they both came back.Almost exactly  years ago, they had their first child, Elisabeth, whose birthday was last month. Olivia, , was also born in Cornwall. Then Ben’s job as an aircraft engineer took them to RAF Valley in Wales, where twins Charlotte and Isabelle, now , came along.Another move took the Sullivans to RAF Benson, in Oxfordshire, and their first boy Noah, now , came along, followed by Evangeline, nine, and eight-year-old Tobias.A sht to Lossiemouth followed, where the family was completed . Twins Leah and Erin, now five, were very premature. Agnes, three, and Joseph, two, are the babies of the family.Zoe isn’t quite sure how they ended up with such a huge family. Ben was one of five siblings, but the couple never made a conscious decision to go big.She said: “We never really said let’s have lots of children. We had Noah and then it was like let’s just keep going – this is quite fun.“The twins were supposed to be the last ones, but we carried on. Joseph is only two, so we still have a whole letime to go.”And is there room for any more in the Sullivan family Zoe would only commit to: “No more have arrived # yet.”From shopping trips to days out, the Sullivans have to plan everything they do.For a while, they had two seven-seater Vauxhall Zafiras to ferry the family around – although at the moment they are down to a single Astra for essential journeys.Zoe revealed the key to a happy le is to get the chores as much done in the morning as possible.She said: “We’re very organised people and the kids are too – that’s the only way that works for us.“I’m up at .am on weekdays, and get a slightly later start at the weekend of am.“We’re a good team. Everybody knows what they’ve got to do and knows when to pitch in.”The Sullivan family fit themselves into a standard four-bedroomed house, with Zoe and Ben in one room, the three boys in another, and the girls split by age in the last two.Zoe admitted: “My dream house would have  or  bedrooms, but that seems a tall order.”Food is on an industrial scale # everything comes in multiples of kilogrammes, and Zoe shops four times a week just to keep everything topped up.In terms of treats and outings, the family keep it to day trips – and it all comes under the budgeting umbrella, with Ben’s salary and child benefit the mainstay of income.Zoe said: “It’s a lot of budgeting. We don’t really have holidays, we just have day trips and do things that are free. We’ll go to a park for the day and have Burger King as a treat. We also spend a lot of time at the beach.“One thing I wish we could have is a holiday – but we don’t go many places that cost money because it’s so expensive.A few years ago, with fewer children, they splashed out on a Landmark season ticket – “but that came to about £, I think”.In terms of the future, Zoe is torn between seeing her children fulfil their potential and dreading the moment when she has an empty house.Olivia is planning art at university – which would make her the first to fly the nest.Zoe said: “I really want her to go, but I’m sad at the same time.”Ben will leave the RAF in the next few years and the family will be looking to buy their own house after living in tied accommodation. They are planning to stay in the Lossie area – as Zoe says: “Although Cornwall was our home, this is the kids’ home.“We’re looking forward to watching the kids grow up – but not too soon, I don’t want to be lonely.”In the meantime, the Sullivan family are finding fame of sorts as one of Britain’s biggest.They will feature in the ITV show on Thursday at pm, and they have their own YouTube channel and Facebook page.Zoe also blogs about everything from mental health to everyday le.She said: “I don’t think I’m necessarily doing it right or better than anyone , but people were interested and asking about it, so I started a blog.“This is just how we do it.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

past with all donations going towards organisations close to his heart.NERVS provides free transportation for the Grampian Health Service.Mark, who is originally from Watford but currently lives in Dinnet, said: #Over the years, I#ve done Lands End to John O#Groats by motorcycle in one day, as well as Lands End to John O#Groats and back to Lands End in just two days.#In , while serving in Grampian Police, I rode a marked police bike to all  of the police force HQ#s at the time on the mainland in  days and , miles for Commando .#The following year, I went to the four furthest most compass points and police memorials for Care of Police Survivors on my motorcycle. And later that year I did a six-hour gym endurance event, lting . tons to raise funds for Commando  again.#After Storm Frank , I arranged a huge fundraiser for the victims in Ballater and raised just over £k in one evening. But as it was me against the  miles ahead, it was crack on and walk.#The first , steps were local # on South Deeside Road, and so on # or I#d have my we drop me off at the far side of Aboyne and I#d walk to Ballater. I did that a few times but the hard surfaces killed my feet.#I did the remaining , steps on a  step circuit around Monaltrie Park in Ballater. I wore a track in the grass too. It was hard butit was easy everyone would do it.#My family thinks I#m barking mad but I#ve never failed in any event, so they support me and know when things are hurting me to give me some time and space to chill out.#Friends were kind enough to chip in with sponsorship too. If memory serves, I raised around £,.#After the walk, I had two weeks off at Christmas and cycled on a gym bike at home the  miles from Lands End to John O#Groats for Care of Police Survivors.#I fancied doing something  on my motorcycle and thought of raising money for NERVS.
